I am a bit conflicted on this game. On one hand, I enjoyed my 40 hours spend with it and I definitely got my money's worth. So it's hard for me not to recommend it on just that basis. But at the same time I see tons of wasted potential with weird design choices and ultimately not that much to actually do, culminating in a game that fundamentally is very solid, but is deeply flawed. And because of this I don't see myself ever coming back to it to grind for the rest of the achievements or to 100% all of it's "content". And I am sure there are some people out there who would not like this game because of those things, so let me talk about them in this review so you can make up your minds.

The first big problem this game has is that it pretends (purposefully or not) to have way, and I mean WAY more things to do than it actually does. The game assaults you with lots of characters, stages, multiple game modes, and a massive list of unlockable things and progression systems. But in reality it is all VERY inflated by re-using content over and over. Some examples: 

-Different stages have next to no differences between one another and no relevant gimmicks to make them stand out or play different 
- Differences between characters are largely just based on different stats and a couple character specific skills, even the character specific mechanics you unlock as you level them up are the same thing across all character (just repackaged with different visuals and stat variations). But every character plays 99% the same way.
- Same skills are repeated multiple times with just their elements or other arbitrary characteristics altered. So the hundreds of skill this game has practically boild down to a few dozen distinctly feeling ones
-Different enemies are just reskins that use the same few attack types. If it was just stage enemies I would not even list it as an issue... but it goes for bosses too.

You get it, this is the patter through the whole game. Everything is stretched so thin, one unique thing is split into a couple more things that are almost the same, just to make the game feel larger than it is. The first time you open this game you might be overwhelmed by just how much stuff there is in front of you, but as you play it is starts feeling very, very small. Ultimately this isn't really a deal breaker, because the amount of unique things here is... alright, it's not too much but not too little. It just feels cheap and lame, the game would've been much better if it had 25% of the "content", but it all felt more unique. And while this is definitely this game's biggest weakness, it ultimately would not detract from it's replayability if it pulled off it's own satisfying gameplay loop.

... Which is where we arrive at the game's the second big problem: balance. The problem here is twofold, and it compounds on itself:

1. The way this game does it's damage formula is just... bad. The way they made the math work forces you into the exact same build path if you ever want to make a good build, and it's not the first game that made this mistake either. This game has both additive and multiplicative damage multipliers. Meaning, a 50% damage boost can either be a 50% increase to all the damage that you do, or just a +50% bonus added to all the other bonuses you already have. On it's own that is not a problem, many games do this and it works well if it's done properly and the devs make both play nice together. Here unfortunately the developers completely dropped the ball. Long story short: the game features many debuffs that stack multiplicatively with your total damage dealt. That alone is immensely powerful, but then they also made those debuffs multiply on top of EACH OTHER. That's right, we are no longer just multiplying things, we are doing FACTORIALS now!! And the worst part of all of this, this is THE ONLY way to increase your damage like this. There is no other way in the game to scale your damage in such an absurd way, which means that if you ever wish to get a "god run", you need these debuffs, and you need to be able to stack them as best as you can.

2. There is an archetype of damage skill that is just... superior. It's the skills that multiply their damage based on either the number of debuff/status stacks on the enemy, or ones that consume said stacks and multiply their damage. Basically: the skills taht scale their damage based on debuff number one way or another. It's not even funny how much better these skills are than all the others. And it's sad to see, because there are other skills in the game that clearly try to be good damage skills too, scaling of different things or having other gimmicks to raise their damage. But the difference in strength between the good ones and the bad ones are so massive, we are talking multiple zeroes at the end of the number differences, you HAVE to use these skills if you want the best results.

And if you add those two problems together, you end up with a game that puts extreme emphasis on skills that either directly apply the debuffs I mentioned earlier or are good at applying them in other ways once you get supporting skills, and then it makes you take the scaling damage skills that scale off either the 3 DOT effects, or the status effects, of which there aren't that many. Suddenly, the hundreds of skills this game has boil down to MAYBE a few dozen actually good ones. And since every character is basically the same and can use the same things, you will end up making the variation of the same build every single time... the only way to enjoy some variety here is to unfortunately play on lower difficulties and intentionally ignore the objectively correct way to build your character. Basically: playing the weak, off-meta build in a hack and slash game. And let's be honest, almost nobody enjoys intentionally gimping themselves in a game like this.


So, all of that sounds pretty bad, right? And yeah, it is. And that's why I will probably never come back to it. But that doesn't change the fact that before I arrived at this point, I got 40 hours of good fun out of it and finished the game, and for those 40 hours the problems I mentioned didn't really surface and were not that big of a part of the game. It was really only after I beat the game's final boss for the first time that I started to think "yeah, I think I'm done, there isn't that much here to enjoy afterwards". So, a careful recommendation for people who enjoy this genre of video games.

Really solid "survivors-like" game. Ever since the release of Vampire Survivors, I've been addicted to these types of games. They're a super reliable and laidback source of fun, and the nature of the genre allows for immense creativity on how different devs tackle things and it kind of forces each game to do its own unique thing and bring something new to the table to distinguish itself from others and to actually gain some traction within this arguably now oversaturated genre.

With that being said, happy to say that Soulstone Survivors will offer a seriously great time. The game feels polished and high quality. The visuals are great. Colourful and stays looking pretty even through the chaos. All the characters, environments, weapons, and item/visual effects are designed well. The game has a well-defined and focused artstyle it's going for. The actual gameplay/combat itself is really fun. The game has dodge mechanics and enemies actually use attacks against you rather than dealing damage by simply just touching you, so it keeps you engaged and on your feet, and it actually makes higher-difficulty/longer runs quite challenging, since you actually have to position yourself well while dealing with tons of enemies and bosses bombarding you with huge, hard-hitting attacks. There are tons of playable characters. All of them having multiple weapons each to choose from that offer different stats and abilities. I also really appreciate that every character has voicelines and their own distinctive personalities, making the game feel more alive. The characters even come with skill trees that can be levelled up to gain stat increases and additional unique abilities, with each character being given [spoiler]an alternate skin[/spoiler] as a reward once fully levelled up. "Runes" are additional things that can be unlocked, and they have the largest impact on gameplay. They can be used to make different builds for all the characters offering things ranging from increasing your XP and material gain, to being able to use other characters' abilities that are typically exclusive to those characters, to lowering your damage in exchange for more dodges/dashes or increasing the damage of your summons... the list goes on. There are tons of things to unlock, different game modes, and the devs have so far been constantly and consistently updating the game and adding new content. For the low price, you're getting potentially hundreds of hours of fun.

This entry in the bullet heaven genre stands out most for its polish. The visuals, and especially the audio and voice acting, are above and beyond what you normally find in these kinds of games.

That's not to say the gameplay is lacking, though. The frequent and exciting boss fights require you to stay on your toes, learning and dodging their attacks while your destruction engine whittles them down. With 22 classes, each with their own special abilities, stat spreads, and skill pools, and three game modes with their own cadence, there's plenty of ways to tweak your builds and experience.

Every mode has an infinitely scaling difficulty option as well, so you're never at risk of having your meta progression make the game too easy. Meanwhile, if you love meta progression, boy will you find a lot of it here.

If I have any criticisms, it's that the visual clutter can make noticing dodge cues anywhere from tricky to downright impossible. There's an opacity slider in the options (that affects your skills, not the enemies') to address the issue, but it'd be nice if there was a more elegant solution that didn't require turning down the very nice visuals they have going on. This is mostly only an issue for late-game builds, and isn't always an issue depending on the skills you pick, but it's very noticeable when it is.

Every game mode feels the same, every character, every weapon you pick, every rune you choose - it all plays fundamentally the same. - The rune system is integrated well with skill choices and builds you can explore.

The depth that is promised is more shallow then a spilt bucket on a hill. 

25+ characters with 5 weapons (eventually for all), each with their own stats, 2 unique abilities per weapon with 3-4 general character abilities, 20+ general abilities, and a passive tree for each character certainly offers a wide variety of builds. Skills that increase in damage based on debuffs on the enemy. Kill enemies until bar is filled, collect something, follow a path, stand in an area. Such minor increases that I'm sure it adds up but seeing a 5% damage increase after putting 5 points into the tree feels like ass when you get that same 5% from a single level up during a run. Perhaps the passive tree grants those increases to the base stats like an additive increase but the game does not explain in any way whether it's additive or multiplicative. If we are talking about games where enemies or players can get cc'd for years otherwise (moba/mmo), then yes diminishing returns are good, but um... not in your survivor game where the point is to become a god. These are all true and the biggest draw, to me, was the in-run upgrade system where you level up and choose 1 of 3 options that allow you to increase your strength via lower cooldowns, more damage, more aoe, crit chance, crit damage, multistrike, combination choices, etc. This all sounds well and good, but there's a fundamental issue. The depth that is promised is more shallow then a spilt bucket on a hill. 

25+ characters with 5 weapons (eventually for all), each with their own stats, 2 unique abilities per weapon with 3-4 general character abilities, 20+ general abilities, and a passive tree for each character certainly offers a wide variety of builds. But you will inevitably run into the glaring issue where certain characters are worse than others by large margins because of the simple fact that there are specific skills that outshine all others in terms of damage. Skills that increase in damage based on debuffs on the enemy. You could roll nothing but damage increase for 1 ability out of the 6 (sometimes 7) that you have and still not reach the damage heights of other skills if that skill does not have a multiplier and im talking a difference of 1000 times greater which will be the difference between that .5s boss fight and a 1-2 minute boss fight or better yet, a 15 minute run versus a 30 minute run. This means you can play as optimized as possible with a build theme you like, but it will take you 3 times as long to complete a run without that multiplier, so if a character does not have a skill, whether unique or common, with that multiplier prepare yourself for a slog as the difficulty increases. But don't worry as you can change that via runes which grant further customization by letting you gain access to those multiplier skills (even if they are supposed to be character specific) but that does mean the character you choose doesn't matter beyond their stats. But what about the passive tree that gives each character a unique mechanic? Pointless. Those mechanics don't change how you play beyond giving you a basic task for a damage boost. Kill enemies until bar is filled, collect something, follow a path, stand in an area. Complete this task and you get a damage boost, but again if you don't have that big multiplier skill you will do no significant increase in damage. And the other passive points? Such minor increases that I'm sure it adds up but seeing a 5% damage increase after putting 5 points into the tree feels like ass when you get that same 5% from a single level up during a run. Perhaps the passive tree grants those increases to the base stats like an additive increase but the game does not explain in any way whether it's additive or multiplicative. The game doesn't really explain anything outside of what debuffs do. 25% increase damage via a rune? Same idea, so the passive tree increases feel like busy work. A task to complete and it feels worse since you can and will fill it all out. Nothing felt special. Each point spent had no thought put into it. Just max the number. But surely there can't be something that brings the skill system down more right? Well there is a very specific rune that lets you pick the same skill multiple times, so really to get the big damages you will run the same ability 6 times, maybe 5 if you can get one good support skill and remember you can get any skill onto any character with the right runes. But what about the in-run level up passives? Surely the customizations shine there- No, they don't. I've unlocked the Blacksmith by maxing out the whole passive tree and by spamming 5 of a skill, I could just select the center option and still incinerate the bosses in seconds. Meanwhile I run the barbarian with the stone hammers with only one level less on the weapon (another upgrade system), choosing as optimally as I can, and had to fight the bosses for 60x'ish longer which also means the run lasts longer too. Of course I grabbed a multiplier skill but it took 17 minutes before it came online because I needed the right boss reward. ALL OF THIS TO SAY, build variety is gone when you have no real choices if you want to push the difficulty higher. You have to take the right skills and those are few. But let's make it worse, because you will turn off the visual effects so that you can avoid the danger zones because you can't see with the sheer intensity of visual vomit on the screen unless you want to be one shotted and the end result means no matter the skill, everything now looks the same and you realize how every build plays the same as well. And a quick note on the dots (quick for me) poison is the best, then doom, then bleed, and lastly fire and the difference between each is staggering and that's without a multiplier skill. Seriously, fire always felt the worst, but to be faiiiiiir I'm not delving into the exact numbers. This is just experience based.

At least in vampire survivors the upgrades are small and limited and more importantly you can keep the effects on screen since you only avoid enemy contact. The permanent stat increases build up over time with no limit and I do mean no limit cause there's something else that limits you in gameplay. Diminishing returns.

Diminishing returns are good... sometimes. If we are talking about games where enemies or players can get cc'd for years otherwise (moba/mmo), then yes diminishing returns are good, but um... not in your survivor game where the point is to become a god. There are buffs that give you increases to specific stats but they lose effectiveness. Example. Colossus grants 2% area increase per stack, so how much area would you have at 2k stacks? 1176%... What about 1k stacks? Roughly 1100%... That means you are punished for investing in area when you can achieve those stack amounts. This goes for all stats save for damage. After 1000% you will see diminishing returns. Even your defensives have DR and at higher difficulties you will not want the level up defensives but the buff defensives that stack. HP is the exception.

So I don't need to be optimized with level ups, just need the right skill and repeat it 5-6 times, but I can't stack buffs to insane degrees cause there's DR, I have to turn off the effects in order to play the game, and the unique mechanics of the characters are glorified damage buffs that don't change gameplay. This basically means there is no diversity in builds. Now granted this is only when pushing the difficulty higher, but this problem appears in the early game meta progression wise and gets worse farther into the end game. If you want to have every build be good, don't increase the difficulty. 

The game modes play the same for the most part and the maps have no gimmicks or real enemy differences so it's just visuals. Bosses do have different moves to a point, but all you do is avoid the danger zone and with enough move speed and dashes, its not hard to do except it doesn't matter when you incinerate a boss in .5s. I had to keep this part short cause character limit exists.

All in all, Soulstone Survivors claims depth while having none. Yes it's fun and for 15 bucks you can get hours of enjoyment, but it's precisely because it boasts that which it does not have that I can't recommend it.

I bought this game back in early access, and since then they've added a METRIC TON of content. seriously, it's probably the biggest action roguelike content-wise compared to the classics like Vampire Survivors, Holocure, Halls of Torment etc.
But here's the thing,  my biggest issue is the same now as it was in early access. 

The core gameplay loop is flawed. Once you hit higher difficulty content, you're basically just dashing around in circles dodging red damage zones and projectiles. Every game mode feels the same, every character, every weapon you pick, every rune you choose - it all plays fundamentally the same. Doesn't matter how many new characters, weapons, or maps they add (which they do for free, massive props for that), it gets repetitive and you find yourself dashing around until the level is over. I recall a dev stream for the 1.0 release where they wanted to address this exact situation to make it less heavy on damage zones, but they never really did. They went a different route instead.
They've added a bunch of new systems (short version):
- Character-specific abilities that make heroes more unique which is GREAT.
- The rune system is integrated well with skill choices and builds you can explore. 
- the expanded talent trees makes you feel that you are always getting stronger, one percent point at a time.
Again there is SO much stuff to unlock and upgrade. 
But boiling it down, you're still just running in circles around red circles and squares.

And here's the most frustrating part: on higher curse runs, you have to turn down visual effects just to see what's happening, so I can't even appreciate what my character is doing or the impact of my skill choices. Monsters die, the screen gets cleared, but the feedback on my character getting progressively stronger is not visually represented.

It's a weird situation. They keep adding more free content instead of going the paid DLC route, which I genuinely respect. But content flooding isn't fixing the fundamental problem. 
The game needs a core gameplay overhaul, not another map, character, weapon, or rune. But I see this happening now as very unlikely.

Looking at this now at the end of 2025, the competition in this niche genre may NOT offer the amount of content that you can get here with all the meta-progression systems but often have a better core loop that makes replaying more fun and rewarding. So I lost hope on this project. I am torn on giving this still a positive but for now, i have no desire to play it again no matter how much bells and whistles they add.
